I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  Nepal  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Kathmandu  Valley  Water  Supply  Improvement 
Project.1 
 
2. 
The  original  project  focuses  on  the  distribution  of  potable  water  to  consumers,  and 
improvements in operating efficiency and service delivery of water supply in Kathmandu Valley. 
The  additional  financing  is  required  to  scale  up  a  well-performing  project.  It  includes  
(i)  expanding  coverage  of  improved  water  supply  services,  including  increasing  household 
connections  to  the  improved  network  from  60,000  to  135,000  households;  (ii)  incorporating 
additional  measures  to  improve  operating  efficiency  and  service  delivery,  such  as  a 
computerized  billing  system  for  the  water  utility  and  building  capacity  for  nonrevenue  water 
management; and (iii) increasing readiness of future investments for water supply augmentation 
to meet long-term demand.2 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

Context. Kathmandu Valley has a high population growth rate. The average growth rate 
3. 
from  2001  to  2011  was  5.3%,  which  is  more  than  three  times  the  national  rate  of  1.4%.3 The 
2011 population of Kathmandu Valley was approximately 2.52 million and is estimated to grow 
to  3.50  million  by  2016.  Rapid  and  largely  unplanned  urban  growth,  lack  of  sustainable  water 
sources, inadequate past investments, and weak management have resulted in low availability 
of  water  and  poor  service  delivery.  Inadequate  access  to  water  has  led  to  increased  disease 
incidence,  health  risks,  and  associated  economic  burdens  that  disproportionately  impact  the 
poor and vulnerable.4 
 
4. 
Government’s  phased  investment  strategy.  To  address  these  challenges,  the 
government updated its ambitious capital investment and asset management program in 2010, 
which  envisages  providing  135  liters  per  capita  per  day  (lpcd)  to  the  residents  of  Kathmandu 
Valley  by  2025  from  the  current  45  lpcd.  The  plan  defines  two  major  phases  for  rehabilitation 
and  expansion  of  the  water  supply  and  wastewater  system.  Phase  1  (2012–2016)  focuses  on 
rehabilitation of existing assets, development of a new water source, and initial expansion of the 
water  distribution  and wastewater  system.  Phase 2 (2016–2025) focuses  on  additional  source 
augmentation and expansion of the water distribution and wastewater system. 
 
5. 
Investments  to  support  phase  1.  In  line  with  phase  1  requirements,  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  the  original  project  on  16  September  2011;  it  became 
effective  on  7  February  2012.5 The  SDR50,482,000  ($80  million)  loan  complements  ongoing 
investments  to  improve  access,  efficiency,  and  reliability  of  water  supply  services  for  the 
residents  of  Kathmandu  Valley  through  improving  the  distribution  system  and  enhancing

Additional  financing.  The  additional  financing  will  support  the  completion  of  phase  1 
6. 
investments  and  will  start  phase  2 investments with a focus  on  distribution  network  expansion 
and  improvement.    The  additional  financing  is  in  line  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy, 
2013–2017 for  Nepal,  which supports  the government’s  development  objective of  accelerated, 
sustainable, and inclusive economic growth.8  
 
7. 
Eligibility  criteria.  ADB’s  eligibility  criteria for  additional financing  have  been met. The 
project is rated as being on track. To date, cumulative contract awards of the original project are 
at $71 million or 97%, disbursements are at $25 million or 35% of the ADB net loan amount, and 
24%  of  pipes  have  been  laid.  The  project  is  on  track  to  achieve  most  targets. 9  Project 
compliance  with  safeguards  has  been  satisfactory  and  risks  have  been  managed  adequately. 
There  is  a  high  degree  of  project  readiness  for  the  additional  financing. 10  The  additional 
financing  will  accelerate  the  focus  on  governance  and  institutional  strengthening  of  the  key 
water  sector 
is  suitable  because  of  
(i)  strong  links  with  the  original  project  in  terms  of  design  and  implementation  arrangements;  
(ii) the high degree of project readiness; (iii) the urgency of completing existing investment gaps, 
such as expansion of the Sundarijal water treatment plant; and (iv) the opportunity to scale up 
the  benefits  of  the  original  project  and  other  related  projects.  The  additional  financing  will 
contribute to the outcome of improved access, efficiency, and reliability of water supply services 
to residents of Kathmandu Valley, including poor women and men.

Development Program did not materialize due to a contractual dispute.12 KUKL is not paying the 
lease  fee  to  the  asset  owner,  the  Kathmandu  Valley  Water  Supply  Management  Board 
(KVWSMB),  since  it  does  not  generate  sufficient  revenues.  While  the  government  has 
commenced  the  recruitment  process  for  KUKL’s  general  manager,  the  process  is  not  yet 
finalized.  Corporate  governance  of  KUKL  through  its  Board  also  needs  to  be  supported  and 
strengthened under the project. The government is also considering its options with respect to

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

10. 
The impact will be sustainable water supply services for residents of Kathmandu Valley. 
The  outcome  will  be  improved  access,  efficiency,  and  reliability  of  water  supply  services  to 
residents  of  Kathmandu  Valley,  including  poor  women  and  men.  The  impact  and  outcome 
statements  are  unchanged  from  the  original  project.  The  original  and  aggregate  targets  are  in 
the revised design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1).

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

21. 
Coordination  with  the  Melamchi  Water  Supply  Project.  The  additional  financing  is 
designed  to  achieve  100  lpcd  by  2020  on  the  assumption  that  170  MLD  of  water  will  be 
available from the MWSP by the end of 2016.20 The government and ADB will monitor progress 
to ensure timely completion of the MWSP. 
 
Nonrevenue water reduction plan. The amount of NRW is difficult to assess due to the 
22. 
lack  of  metering  and  intermittent  supply.  The  overall  project  uses  the  district  metering  area 
approach to reduce NRW from higher than 50% currently to less than 20% in areas where DNI 
will be carried out.21 The DNI bidding documents will include incentives for NRW reduction and 
installation of around 75,000 new meters. The project will also support KUKL in strengthening its 
NRW management at headquarters and branches under output 2. 
 
23. 
Technical support systems. The BDS will be linked to a remote monitoring system for 
real-time  data  monitoring  and  active  leakage  control.22 The  GIS  system  is  being  updated  and 
improved  under  the  original  project  and  the  additional  financing  will  continue  to  build  KUKL’s 
capacity to use a GIS as a planning and decision-making tool. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

24. 
Economic  analysis.  The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  all 
related investments, including the original project, the MWSP, Japan International Cooperation 
Agency-financed  water  treatment  plant,  and  the  additional  financing  is  16.06%.  The  EIRR  is 
higher  than  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12%,  indicating  sufficient  economic 
return. The results from a sensitivity analysis, which range from  11.40% to 16.03%, are robust 
and  satisfactory  against  downside  risks,  including  a  10%  increase  in  capital  expenditure 

                                                
20 High service in Nepal is defined as 135 lpcd, which is the objective for Kathmandu Valley by 2025 with additional 
supply from Melamchi phase 2. The target of 100 lpcd (medium-service) will be met by 2020 with the project during 
the wet season. Estimates for the dry season (about 4 months per year) are 86 lpcd.

(14.69%),  a  10%  increase  in  operating  costs  (16.03%),  a  10%  decrease  in  benefits  or  the 
number of beneficiaries (14.51%), and a 3-year delay in project completion (11.40%). The EIRR 
is relatively more sensitive to project delays and reduction in benefits. The large and expanding 
population  with  progressive  productivity  gains  indicates  that  the  risk  of  substantial  benefit 
reduction is highly unlikely. Project readiness for the additional financing is high. While delay in 
project completion is unlikely, exogenous risks including the availability of water and the delay in 
MWSP implementation could lead to a delay in fully attaining project benefits. 
 
25. 
Financial  analysis.  The estimated financial internal rate of return of the overall project 
including the additional financing is 1.25%. The financial internal rate of return is slightly higher 
than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  estimated  at  1.24%,  indicating  adequate  financial 
return. The  sensitivity  analysis  reveals  that financial  viability  of the  project  is most  sensitive  to 
project delays and decreases in revenue. KUKL raised the water tariff by an average of 30% in 
2009  and  80%  in  2013,  however  its  ability  to  charge  and  collect  the  water  tariff  is  highly 
dependent  on  its  ability  to  provide  services.  Assuming  sufficient  source  augmentation,  the 
overall  project  will  substantially  improve  the  distribution  network  in  Kathmandu  Valley 
municipalities. To improve operating efficiency, KUKL is in urgent need of a computerized billing 
and  accounting  system,  which  the  additional  financing  will  support.  KUKL  will  continue  to 
execute its 5-year business plan together with other efforts to improve asset management and 
revenue enhancement. 
 
C. 

Governance 

26. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are 
described in the PAM. The overall financial management risk assessment for  KUKL, MWSDB, 
and KVWSMB  is  low;  the project financial management  systems  are  considered  adequate.  All 
three  implementing  agencies  lack  fully  computerized  accounting  systems,  but  MWSDB  and 
KUKL  have  extensive  experience  with  ADB  projects,  and  MWSDB  and  KVWSMB  engage  a 
chartered  accountant.  KUKL  staff  require  appropriate  training  to  ensure  operation  of  the 
computerized billing system. Detailed accounting and auditing arrangements are in the PAM. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

27. 
The  project  is  classified  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  A  poverty  and  social 
analysis  was  completed 23 and  the  project  will  serve  low-income  areas.  The  government  is 
expected  to  reform  the  current  water  connection  policy  (2008)  to  facilitate  individual  water 
connections  to  the  poor,  socially  excluded,  and  households  headed  by  women;  and  reduce 
connection  fees  for  poor  households.24 The  GESI  action  plan  was  updated  and  includes  clear 
targets,  responsibilities,  and  resource  allocation.25 The  additional  financing  will  strengthen  the 
recently established KUKL GESI unit. The updated community awareness and participation plan 
involves  key  stakeholders  for  widespread,  ongoing,  and  meaningful  participation. 26 PID  will 
implement  the  GESI  action  plan  and  the  community  awareness  and  participation  plan  with 
support  from  community  awareness  and  participation  experts  recruited  under  the  project 
through the DSC.

 E. 

Safeguards 

28. 
The  safeguard  categories  are  the  same  as  for  the  original  project:  category  B  for 
environment and involuntary resettlement, and category C for indigenous peoples. Compliance 
with  safeguard  requirements  in  the  original  project  has  been  satisfactory  and  risks  well 
managed. Regular reporting and monitoring on safeguard compliance is required during project 
implementation. Safeguard documents for the additional financing  have been disclosed on the 
websites of ADB, MWSDB, and PID. 
 
29. 
Social  safeguards.  The  additional  financing  will  have  limited  impacts  on  involuntary 
resettlement. The identified impacts are mostly temporary income loss for vendors, hawkers, or 
informal  land  users  on  government  land  during  construction.  The  land  for  all  reservoirs  was 
acquired  under  the  MWSP  with  no  pending  issues.  No  impacts  on  indigenous  peoples  have 
been  identified  at  the  project  sites.  The  additional  financing  will  support  the  recruitment  of 
community awareness and participation and social safeguard experts to (i) continue to build PID 
capacity, (ii) support public communications and interactions with civil society organizations, and 
(iii) monitor compliance with social safeguard requirements. An updated resettlement framework 
to  mitigate  possible  involuntary  resettlement  impacts  during  project  implementation  was 
prepared  and  endorsed  by  KUKL.  The  three  resettlement  plans  prepared  for  the  additional 
financing  will  need  to  be  updated  following  completion  of  detailed  designs,  endorsed  by  ADB, 
and implemented  prior  to contract  award.  Separate  due  diligence reports  have been  prepared 
for  the  BDS  package to be  partially financed under the  additional financing  and  a  small  works 
package to confirm no negative impacts. 
 
Environmental safeguards. The environmental assessment and review framework has 
30. 
been  updated  to  guide  the  environmental  assessment  of  small  components  to  be  defined 
through  detailed  design  after  approval.  An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  with  an 
environmental  management  plan,  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement  (2009),  did  not  identify  any  significant  adverse  impacts.  Adverse  impacts  related  to 
the  expected  increase  in  volume  of  wastewater  are mitigated through the  ongoing  Kathmandu 
Valley  Wastewater  Management  Project,  which  is  rehabilitating  and  expanding  the  sewerage 
network  and  wastewater treatment.  Additional  oversight  and mitigation  measures  will  be  taken 
for pipe-laying works along roads passing through heritage areas, including permission from the 
Department of Archaeology prior to construction. The IEE will be disclosed following its approval 
by MOUD and ADB. The IEE and the environmental management plan will be updated following 
detailed designs. They will be submitted to ADB for no objection and then incorporated into civil 
works bidding documents and disclosed.
